column4: I remember hearing once that you can use a spare flashcard as some sort of cache for the hard drive, but I've been googling around and can't seem to find anything on this
anyone know what I'm talking about?
no but you can have a /swap partition on it, and mount at boot via fstab
hm, I'm not sure swap ever gets hit here
how much ram you got?
about 4 gigs
ssd for / as well?
hah, one day I'll be able to afford a big ssd, but that day is not today
so why would you want to cache on flash memory with less read/write speed than a reg 7200rpm hdd?
I figured that another 512MB would be useful, that's 1/8th of ram, and would let me increase preload's caching
given flash memory's limited r/w
like I care? flash can take a lot of r/w, there's wear-leveling, and if the card dies in a few years, I just shrug and trash it
what gpu, and are you compositing?
no compositing (running xmonad) and the card is ATI Mobility Radeon HD 5650 1G
it's not a bad card, and my older computers were much faster with nvidia cards. so I blame the driver
problem solved. ati support for linux is essentially near crap, its only recently they provided open source drivers
well, that's why I blame the driver...
have you tried experimenting with kms?
with what?
kernel mode setting its a new feature but its cause more problems for some
I'll look into that I guess
only if the keybindings are set up for that. I do just fine with one hand with xmonad
same here when i'm feeling lazy on dwm
